canonical_explanation.text: Data handling means collecting, recording, and reading information. We can collect data by counting objects or asking questions. We record data using tally marks — each tally mark stands for 1 item. We group tally marks in sets of 5 (four vertical lines crossed by one diagonal line = 5). A pictograph uses pictures to show data. Each picture in a simple pictograph stands for 1 item. We can answer questions by looking at the data: which has the most, which has the least, how many in total, and how many more or fewer.
rules: Data is information collected by counting or asking questions.
Tally marks are used to record counts. Each mark = 1 item.
Every 5 tally marks are grouped: four vertical lines crossed by one diagonal line (||||̸ = 5).
A pictograph uses small pictures to show how many items are in each group.
In a simple pictograph, 1 picture = 1 item.
'Most' means the largest count; 'Least' means the smallest count.
To find the total, add all the counts together.
To find 'how many more', subtract the smaller count from the larger count.

questions.question_text: What does 'data' mean?

options.text: Information collected by counting or asking questions

questions.explanation_correct: Data is information that we collect by counting things or asking questions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data means information. We collect data by counting objects or asking people questions.

questions.question_text: Riya counts how many red, blue, and green marbles she has. She is:
questions.explanation_correct: When Riya counts her marbles by colour, she is collecting data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Counting objects and sorting them into groups is a way of collecting data.

questions.question_text: Aman asks his classmates what their favourite fruit is. He is:
questions.explanation_correct: Asking classmates questions and recording their answers is collecting data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asking people questions to gather information is a way of collecting data.

questions.question_text: What is a tally mark?

options.text: A line used to count items (each line = 1)

questions.explanation_correct: A tally mark is a vertical line used to count. Each line stands for 1 item.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Tally marks are simple lines used to keep count. One line = one item.

questions.question_text: How many items does this tally represent: |||| (4 lines)?
questions.explanation_correct: 4 tally marks = 4 items. Each line represents 1 item.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each tally mark represents 1 item. Four lines = 4 items.

questions.question_text: After every 4 tally marks, what do we do with the 5th mark?

options.text: Draw it on a new line
Draw a diagonal line across the 4 marks to make a group of 5

questions.explanation_correct: The 5th tally mark is drawn as a diagonal line across the first 4. This makes counting by 5s easier.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We group tally marks in sets of 5: four vertical lines crossed by one diagonal line. This helps us count by 5s.

questions.question_text: A group of 5 tally marks (one crossed set) equals how many?
questions.explanation_correct: One group of tally marks (4 lines with a diagonal cross) = 5.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A complete group of tally marks has 4 vertical lines and 1 crossing diagonal line = 5 items total.

questions.question_text: Two groups of 5 tally marks represent how many items?
questions.explanation_correct: Two groups of 5 = 5 + 5 = 10 items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each group of tally marks = 5. Two groups = 5 + 5 = 10.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph, each small picture represents:
questions.explanation_correct: In a simple pictograph (Class 2 level), each picture represents 1 item.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a simple pictograph, 1 picture = 1 item. We count the pictures to find how many.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Apples - 6 pictures, Bananas - 4 pictures, Oranges - 3 pictures. Which fruit has the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Apples have 6 pictures — the most. Bananas have 4 and oranges have 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 6 is greater than 4 and 3. Apples (6) have the most pictures.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Cats - 5 pictures, Dogs - 8 pictures, Fish - 3 pictures. Which pet has the least?
questions.explanation_correct: Fish have 3 pictures — the least. Cats have 5 and dogs have 8.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 is the smallest number. Fish (3) have the fewest pictures.

questions.question_text: True or False: Counting how many students like different colours is collecting data.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Asking students about their favourite colours and recording the counts is collecting data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Gathering information by counting or asking questions is called collecting data.

questions.question_text: True or False: Tally marks are grouped in sets of 10.
questions.explanation_correct: False. Tally marks are grouped in sets of 5, not 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We group tally marks in sets of 5: four vertical marks crossed by one diagonal mark.

questions.question_text: Meera counted 7 butterflies using tally marks. How would this look?

options.text: One group of 5 and 2 more marks
One group of 5 and 3 more marks

questions.explanation_correct: 7 = one group of 5 (crossed set) + 2 individual marks.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 7 in tally marks: one complete group of 5 plus 2 more lines. 5 + 2 = 7.

questions.question_text: Arjun's tally marks show: one group of 5, then 4 more marks. How many items did he count?
questions.explanation_correct: One group of 5 + 4 more = 5 + 4 = 9 items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: One group of 5 tally marks plus 4 individual marks = 9 total.

questions.question_text: How many tally marks represent 12?
questions.explanation_correct: 12 = two groups of 5 + 2 individual marks. 5 + 5 + 2 = 12.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 12 in tally marks: two complete groups of 5 (= 10) plus 2 more lines (= 2). Total = 12.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows favourite sports: Cricket - 10 pictures, Football - 7 pictures, Kabaddi - 5 pictures. How many students chose cricket?
questions.explanation_correct: Cricket has 10 pictures. Each picture = 1 student, so 10 students chose cricket.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In this pictograph, each picture = 1 student. Cricket has 10 pictures = 10 students.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Roses - 8, Sunflowers - 5, Marigolds - 7. How many flowers are there in total?
questions.explanation_correct: Total = 8 + 5 + 7 = 20 flowers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all the counts: 8 (Roses) + 5 (Sunflowers) + 7 (Marigolds) = 20 total.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Red balls - 9, Blue balls - 6. How many more red balls are there than blue balls?
questions.explanation_correct: 9 − 6 = 3 more red balls than blue balls.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find 'how many more', subtract: 9 − 6 = 3. There are 3 more red balls.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Pencils - 4, Pens - 7, Crayons - 9. Which item has the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Crayons have 9 — the most. Pens have 7 and pencils have 4.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9 is the largest number. Crayons (9) have the most pictures.

questions.question_text: Ananya wants to find out which snack her class likes most. She should:

options.text: Ask each student and record the answers

questions.explanation_correct: To collect data properly, she should ask each student in the class and record their answers.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Collecting data means asking everyone and recording the information, not guessing.

questions.question_text: A pictograph uses star pictures to show how many students like each colour. Blue has 6 stars, Green has 6 stars, Red has 4 stars. Which colours are equally liked?
questions.explanation_correct: Blue and Green both have 6 stars — they are equally liked.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Blue = 6, Green = 6. They are equal. Red = 4, which is different.

questions.question_text: Kabir used tally marks to count birds. He has three groups of 5. How many birds did he count?
questions.explanation_correct: Three groups of 5 = 5 + 5 + 5 = 15 birds.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Each tally group = 5. Three groups = 5 × 3 = 15.

questions.question_text: A data table shows: Mango - 12, Apple - 8, Banana - 10. How many more mangoes than apples are there?
questions.explanation_correct: 12 − 8 = 4 more mangoes than apples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find 'how many more', subtract: 12 − 8 = 4.

questions.question_text: True or False: To collect data about favourite animals, you can ask each person and count the answers.
questions.explanation_correct: True. Asking people and counting their responses is a way to collect data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Asking questions and counting responses is one of the most common ways to collect data.

questions.question_text: Fill in the blank: Two groups of 5 tally marks plus 1 more mark equals ___ items.
questions.explanation_correct: Two groups of 5 = 10, plus 1 = 11.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows how many books each child read. Sita - 5 books, Ram - 8 books, Gita - 3 books, Hari - 6 books. Who read the most books?
questions.explanation_correct: Ram read 8 books — the most. Hari read 6, Sita read 5, and Gita read 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 8 is the largest number. Ram (8) read the most books.

questions.question_text: Using the same data (Sita - 5, Ram - 8, Gita - 3, Hari - 6), who read the fewest books?
questions.explanation_correct: Gita read 3 books — the fewest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 3 is the smallest number. Gita (3) read the fewest books.

questions.question_text: Using the same data (Sita - 5, Ram - 8, Gita - 3, Hari - 6), how many books did all four children read in total?
questions.explanation_correct: 5 + 8 + 3 + 6 = 22 books in total.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all: 5 + 8 + 3 + 6 = 22 total books.

questions.question_text: Using the same data (Sita - 5, Ram - 8, Gita - 3, Hari - 6), how many more books did Ram read than Gita?
questions.explanation_correct: Ram read 8, Gita read 3. 8 − 3 = 5 more books.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To find 'how many more': 8 − 3 = 5. Ram read 5 more books than Gita.

questions.question_text: A student recorded tally marks for different vehicles she saw: Cars - two groups of 5 plus 3 marks, Buses - one group of 5 plus 1 mark, Autos - one group of 5 plus 4 marks. How many cars did she see?
questions.explanation_correct: Cars: two groups of 5 = 10, plus 3 = 13.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two groups of 5 = 10. Plus 3 more = 13 cars.

questions.question_text: Using the vehicle data (Cars - 13, Buses - 6, Autos - 9), which vehicle did she see the most?
questions.explanation_correct: Cars were seen 13 times — the most. Autos were 9 and buses were 6.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 13 is the largest number. She saw the most cars.

questions.question_text: Using the vehicle data (Cars - 13, Buses - 6, Autos - 9), how many vehicles did she see in total?
questions.explanation_correct: 13 + 6 + 9 = 28 vehicles in total.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all: 13 + 6 + 9 = 28 total vehicles.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Chocolate ice cream - 12, Vanilla - 8, Strawberry - 10, Mango - 15. Which flavour is the most popular?
questions.explanation_correct: Mango has 15 pictures — the most. It is the most popular flavour.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 15 is the largest number. Mango (15) is the most popular.

questions.question_text: Using the ice cream data (Chocolate - 12, Vanilla - 8, Strawberry - 10, Mango - 15), how many more students chose Mango than Vanilla?
questions.explanation_correct: 15 − 8 = 7 more students chose Mango than Vanilla.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mango: 15, Vanilla: 8. Difference = 15 − 8 = 7.

questions.question_text: Which is the best way to find out which game is most popular in your class?

options.text: Ask every student and count the answers

questions.explanation_correct: The best way is to ask every student and count all their answers. This gives complete data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: To get accurate data, you should ask every student, not just one or a few.

questions.question_text: Nisha has four groups of 5 tally marks plus 2 more marks. How many items did she count?
questions.explanation_correct: Four groups of 5 = 20, plus 2 = 22 items.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 4 × 5 = 20, plus 2 = 22 total items.

questions.question_text: In a pictograph about fruits, each apple picture represents 1 apple. If there are 7 apple pictures, how many apples are there?
questions.explanation_correct: Each picture = 1 apple. 7 pictures = 7 apples.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In this simple pictograph, 1 picture = 1 item. So 7 pictures = 7 apples.

questions.question_text: Fill in the blank: Information collected by counting things is called ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Information collected by counting is called data.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Data means information gathered by counting or asking questions.

questions.question_text: Fill in the blank: We group tally marks in sets of ___.
questions.explanation_correct: Tally marks are grouped in sets of 5 for easy counting.
questions.explanation_incorrect: We make groups of 5: four lines with a diagonal cross = 5 items.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows favourite subjects: Maths - 9, English - 6, Hindi - 8, Science - 7. Which subject do the fewest students like?
questions.explanation_correct: English has 6 — the fewest. Hindi has 8, Science has 7, and Maths has 9.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 6 is the smallest number. English (6) has the fewest students.

questions.question_text: Using the subjects data (Maths - 9, English - 6, Hindi - 8, Science - 7), how many students were asked in total?
questions.explanation_correct: 9 + 6 + 8 + 7 = 30 students in total.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all: 9 + 6 + 8 + 7 = 30 total students.

questions.question_text: Using the subjects data (Maths - 9, English - 6, Hindi - 8, Science - 7), how many more students like Maths than English?
questions.explanation_correct: Maths: 9, English: 6. Difference = 9 − 6 = 3.
questions.explanation_incorrect: 9 − 6 = 3 more students like Maths than English.

questions.question_text: True or False: In a simple pictograph, we can find out which item has the most by counting which row has the most pictures.
questions.explanation_correct: True. The row with the most pictures represents the item with the highest count.
questions.explanation_incorrect: In a pictograph, the longer row (more pictures) shows the item with the most count.

questions.question_text: Tanya recorded tally marks for flowers in her garden: Rose - one group of 5 plus 2 marks, Jasmine - two groups of 5, Marigold - one group of 5 plus 4 marks. How many jasmine flowers are there?
questions.explanation_correct: Jasmine: two groups of 5 = 5 + 5 = 10.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Two groups of 5 tally marks = 10 jasmine flowers.

questions.question_text: Using Tanya's flower data (Rose - 7, Jasmine - 10, Marigold - 9), how many flowers are there in all?
questions.explanation_correct: 7 + 10 + 9 = 26 flowers in total.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Add all: 7 (Rose) + 10 (Jasmine) + 9 (Marigold) = 26 flowers.

questions.question_text: A pictograph about birds shows: Sparrow - 11, Crow - 8, Parrot - 6, Pigeon - 9. How many parrots were seen?
questions.explanation_correct: Parrot has 6 pictures = 6 parrots were seen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Look at the parrot row: 6 pictures = 6 parrots.

questions.question_text: Using the bird data (Sparrow - 11, Crow - 8, Parrot - 6, Pigeon - 9), how many fewer parrots than sparrows were seen?
questions.explanation_correct: 11 − 6 = 5 fewer parrots than sparrows.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sparrow: 11, Parrot: 6. Difference = 11 − 6 = 5 fewer parrots.

questions.question_text: After collecting data, what should you do to organize it?

options.text: Record it using tally marks or a table

questions.explanation_correct: After collecting data, you should record and organize it using tally marks, a table, or a pictograph.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Organizing data with tally marks or tables helps us understand and compare the information.

questions.question_text: A pictograph shows: Dosa - 14, Idli - 10, Paratha - 12, Poha - 8. Which two breakfast items together have the same total as Dosa?
questions.explanation_correct: Dosa = 14. Idli + Poha = 18, Paratha + Poha = 20, Idli + Paratha = 22. None equal 14.
questions.explanation_incorrect: No pair of the other items adds up to exactly 14. The closest is not an exact match.
